chapter.title: Preamble
chapter.text: We, the CONstituents of the CONsortium — having resolved to ensure long-lasting CONsensus of moderation, perpetuate burocracy, and formalize shenanigans — do hereby adopt and commit to upholding this CONstitution.

section.title: Supreme Leaders
section.text: Supreme Leader is a title that a CONstituent may carry.

list.intro: The following CONstituents are Supreme Leaders:
list.item: shelvacu#8719 (discord id 165858230327574528)
metanomial#0001 (discord id 155438323354042368)

section.text: Supreme Leaders may do anything by unanimous informal vote of all current Supreme Leaders. This is an override vote.
A message must call for an override vote somehow. A motion in which all Supreme Leaders have voted in favor does not trigger an override vote.

chapter.title: Fungibles
chapter.text: Fungibles are indivisible units of currency — owned by CONstituents and/or Discord users — that may be useful for other purposes.

Fungibles can not be
created
destroyed
except as specifically authorized in
super motions
this CONstitution .

section.title: Protection from transfer
section.text: Fungibles can not be transferred without the explicit consent of the current owner.

Making an action to
cast a vote
create a motion that requires votes
counts as explicit consent to remove the necessary PC.

section.title: Generators
section.text: Every day at midnight UTC all owners of any generators receive one PC for each generator they own at that moment.

section.title: Privacy of fungibles
section.text: The amount of fungibles owned by a person (their balances) is private, and must not be revealed without their explicit consent.

list.intro: The transactions that a person has participated in are private, and must not be revealed unless:
list.item: The transaction is a vote on a motion.
The transaction is creating a motion.
At least one party has given explicit consent.

section.text:
The protections in this section shall not be construed to
prohibit
restrict
the public
transfer
fabrication
destruction
of fungibles, even if such may in effect reveal details about a person's
balances
transactions .

chapter.title: Motions

list.intro: A motion is a proposed action to be taken by the CONsortium as an entity in theory, and once passed allows members to take action to implement it in practice. This includes but is not limited to:
list.item: Making changes to the discord server
Declarations
Adopting administrative procedures
Amending tomes, including The CONstitution

chapter.text: A motion is first proposed, after which it is pending during which it can be voted on, then possibly passed. A motion can not have any effect before it is passed.

list.intro: There are two kinds of motions:

section.title: Simple motions
section.text: Simple motions require more than half of the votes on the motion to be in favor to pass.
Simple motions are limited in that they are less powerful than the CONstitution.

Simple motions cannot
amend
override
the CONstitution.

section.title: Super motions
section.text: Super motions require more than two-thirds of the votes on the motion to be in favor to pass.
Super motions are not at all limited. Super motions can do anything once passed, including but not limited to amending or overriding the CONstitution.

section.title: Calling motions
section.text: All CONstituents have the inalienable right to call motions if they have enough pc to do so and have not exceeded their daily limit.
Each CONstituent is limited to proposing 10 motions (no matter which kind) per UTC day.
To call a simple motion, a CONstituent must have enough PC to vote for that motion at least **once**. When called, they do and must vote for that motion at least **once**.
To call a super motion, a CONstituent must have enough PC to vote for that motion at least **twice**. When called, they do and must vote for that motion at least **twice**.

section.title: Voting on motions
section.text: A vote is an irreversible action taken by a CONstituent that costs pc and potentially effects the result of motions.
All CONstituents have the inalienable right to vote on pending motions if they have enough pc to do so.
A CONstituent cannot change the direction (in favor or against) of their vote after their first vote, including 0-votes.

Each CONstituent's first vote on each motion costs 40 PC. The cost of each additional vote by that CONstituent on that motion is 40×(1.05^N) rounded down, where N is the number of votes that CONstituent has already cast on that motion.
Who voted on a motion, in which direction, when, and how many votes shall be a matter of public record.

section.title: End of a motion
section.text: A motion ends when the motion's potential result (pass or fail based on the number of votes) hasn't changed for 48 hours. At that moment, the motion can no longer be voted on, and goes into effect if it passes.

chapter.title: Order of precedence
chapter.text: The law and prescribed actions of the CONsortium are the whole sum of the CONstitution and all passed motions, taken together.

list.intro: Sections of the CONstitution and/or sections of motions (texts) may contradict eachother; If so, the first applicable item below resolves the contradiction:
list.item:
Super motions
the CONstitution
take precedence over simple motions.
If a text says it overrides the other (or other similar phrasing) but not vice-versa, then it does.
The text that passed later overrides the text that was passed earlier.

list.intro: In case of any vagueness or simple lack of mentioning, the following defaults apply. This does not prohibit texts from explicitly specifying a different meaning.
list.item: If a time of day is mentioned, it is assumed to be in Pacific Time as used by the state of Washington.

If a text depends on when a message was
"posted"
"sent"
similar , it is assumed to be the timestamp assigned to the message by discord, obtainable by extracting it from the snowflake ID.
A text that is phrased as changing some state of the universe is assumed to mean the CONsortium shall take action to make that change happen.
A supermotion that does things not allowed by the CONstitution implicitly ammends the CONstitution to allow it to do those things, and no other changes.
A text that requires the destruction of fungibles can be satisfied by the owner of those fungibles voluntarily transferring the correct number of fungibles to the (non-existant) user id 1.
